author: butta
content: _thread_

author: sky.cactus
content: In my experience, all of the anti-1559 detractors are unwilling to engage in actual long-form conversation, debate, and education.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is all just people with hot takes who have either not spent a whole lot of time thinking about the problem, or they have but they have isolated themselves in an echo chamber and aren't actually talking to the right people.

author: sky.cactus
content: Maybe there are exceptions to this, but that has generally been the feeling I get when I try to engage with anti-1559 people.  As soon as you try to dig in on the issues they check out.

author: butta
content: most of them are either wallet devs or dapp devs sooo ðŸ˜„

author: sky.cactus
content: There are definitely some wallet developers who fall into these traps. They are not immune to echochambers and unwillingness to engage.

author: butta
content: that's the problem with theoretical researchers, they are usually far from practise/reality

author: sky.cactus
content: However, there are many wallet devs who *have* engaged with us and dug in deep and the feedback I have seen from them is generally positive once they get past the instinctual roadblocks that everyone (including many of us champions!) have.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm not a researcher.  I run an Ethereum support company and deal with end-user support issues all day.  ðŸ™‚

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: I'm the OP in linked thread and have engaged in there though, and am happy to engage in longer form dialogue. and im pro-1559 for security reasons. just feel this improves UX only for a minority of users who need trades to go in immediately (cant wait to fail and retry) and are therefore willing to pay on spikes.

author: sky.cactus
content: "Fail and retry" is a *really bad* experience for new users.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is significantly better for users to simply see a price that they are unwilling to pay and walk away (perhaps coming back later) than it is for them to try and then have to deal with a pending transaction.

author: sky.cactus
content: If you haven't seen it already, here is a "story form" of what the experience is like for new users right now: https://medium.com/coinmonks/a-tale-of-two-pricing-schemes-dc9c8717906

author: sky.cactus
content: The goal of 1559 isn't to give better tools to power users who are timing gas price seasonality.  It is to improve the user experience for new users to Ethereum who don't have any idea what gas is.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content:
a) wallets can improve UX of failed tx, replace-by-fee and showing historical gasprices, if they did it properly.

b) ethereum is expensive af and hence its worth it for 'new but not wealthy' users to spend 30 min learning how gas and failed tx works. there's already a steep learning curve with seed phrases and security and specific dapps, might as well learn some more. need educational content. long run it saves a lot of money. and max willingness-to-pay and then expect refund is not a very easy concept to explain either

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: your example of seeing high fee and walking away works both pre and post 1559, not sure why its pro either

author: sky.cactus
content:
> wallets can improve UX of failed tx, replace-by-fee and showing historical gasprices, if they did it properly.
This requires the wallet remain open (with keys in decrypted in memory), and it requires the user agree to the highest possible fee in advance (which is basically what 1559 does with a good UI), or the wallet will need to charge the user a fee higher than the user originally agreed to, or the wallet will need to constantly re-prompt the user.

author: sky.cactus
content:
Pre-London, if you set a high gas price and walk away you pay the full gas price.
Post-London, if you set a high max fee and walk away, you pay the minimum required for inclusion.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: oh okay not saying wallet sends tx (although thats another solution)

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: just saying display this on one page intuitively

author: sky.cactus
content: Bidding on a live fee market is something that is very foreign to new users.  The whole concept of variable fees is complicated enough, but then adding on the complexity of participating in a first price auction is a huge leap in terms of new user concepts.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: oh you mean send the tx and walk away. imo more likely ppl see high fees and walk away without sending tx

author: sky.cactus
content: That is fine, in fact it is exactly the behavior we want.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content:
is auction simpler than pay high and refund?
it can definitely be made intuitive, show a chart of historical gasprice and ask ppl to guess (which is what they do rn as power users)

author: sky.cactus
content: It makes the process of decision making simple for end-users.  Agree to pay or not.  If you agree to pay you get included (quickly), if you don't agree to pay then you can come back later and see if fees are any different.

author: sky.cactus
content: History does not predict future.  The problem here is that gas prices are *insantaneous* demand for blockspace aggregated across thousands of individuals around the world operating independently.

author: sky.cactus
content: This means that demand can change very rapidly, and in unexpected ways.  Even just having a block that mines slowly can shift demand significantly, not to mention major events occurring around the world, time zones, seasonality, etc.

author: sky.cactus
content:
People have spent a lot of time and energy trying to write a predictive oracle, and they all run into problems and fail to achieve the desired goal of simplifying the auction process.  Ultimately, end users are the ones that participate in the auction and the two most common outcomes are:
1. Overpay.
2. Underpay and get stuck.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content:
so youre in favour of paying more and simpler decision, rather than save money but think more. if a user wants to pay more and not risk fail tx they can do that pre-1559 also (ofc they lose more money then).
I guess the question is do we want new users to learn how gas works (if not on first day but soon), imo yes you say no

author: sky.cactus
content: With 1559 people pay less (very marginally, not significant) *and* they have a simpler decision.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: getting stuck wouldnt be an issue if wallets showed failed tx and speeding up properly

author: sky.cactus
content: People who *do* want to engage it gas price seasonality can still do so with 1559.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: its not protocol level issue

author: sky.cactus
content: As I mentioned above, the UX for dealing with stuck transactions at the wallet level has some bad tradeoffs no matter how you solve it.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: i didnt understand this, im not saying wallet must have access to kets or anything

author: sky.cactus
content: Wallets always have access to keys.  However, you don't necessarily want your wallet to keep those "hot" at all times.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: just saying pending tx should be considered no-op and easy to explain, and user can try again. wallets can make that easy

author: sky.cactus
content: And users want to be able to walk away.

author: sky.cactus
content: Right, one solution is to just do RbF.  MetaMask has this feature.

author: sky.cactus
content: The problem here is that users have to babysit their transactions, and they have to participate in this repeated first price auction, which can be a very frustrating experience for new users.

author: sky.cactus
content: You submit a transaction (initial expectation is that if you pay the listed fee it will go through), but then it doesn't go through.  You then do a replace-by-fee (a concept that users don't understand, and the wallet just calls "speed up").  Sometimes this will still fail.

author: sky.cactus
content: This all assumes the user even *realizes* that they need to "speed up" the transaction.  Many new users just try to click submit again in whatever UI they are using, which often results in multiple transactions (definitely not the user's intention).

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: because wallet doesnt communicate that you may need to speed up if youre in hurry, and wallet doesnt communicate historical gasprice or anything

author: sky.cactus
content: TL;DR: Wallets have been trying to fix this first price auction UX for a while, and it turns out it is a really hard problem with lots of sharp edges that users find themselves getting cut on.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: or metamask isnt good at UX

author: sky.cactus
content: Giving user a gas price chart is definitely not something appropriate for new users.  That is very much a power user or trader interface.

author: sky.cactus
content: For a new user, the easiest UX is to give them a single fee to agree to, and if they agree then you nearly guarantee they get included while also ensuring they don't overpay.

author: sky.cactus
content: A wallet *can* give the user more information so they can actively participate in a first price auction, but the vast majority of humans don't want to spend their day doing micro first price auctions.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: i lean a bit towards ethereum itself not be appropriate for the kind of user youre thinking of, but not sure

author: sky.cactus
content: They want to click a button, know what it will cost (max) and move on with their life.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: maybe can ask actual new users

author: sky.cactus
content: What is nice about 1559 is that power users can still participate in the first price auction and timing of gas seasonality if they want.  1559 just *enables* users to not to do that instead.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: agreed. dont think there's major harm from 1559

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: power users now have 2 fees to set instead of one, still a pain but maybe thats ok

author: sky.cactus
content: If your argument is, "Ethereum shouldn't try to attract/support novice users" then I can appreciate the conclusion that "1559 doesn't help significantly" because it is helping a group of people who you don't think we should be trying to help.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think I probably classify as a "power user" and 1559 transactions have made my life much simpler.

author: sky.cactus
content: I sent a transaction the other day with a 1000 nanoeth `maxFeePerGas` and a 1 nanothe `maxPremiumPerGas` and it was great not having to bother looking at any tooling.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: novice users who arent technical enough to understand some finance or some technical part. they dont need to know its an auction but i dont see looking at past price and guessing as beyond capability of new user (if they have are a bit technical)

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: or speeding up

author: sky.cactus
content:
I just submitted my transaction without any effort/thought and was happy to know that:
1. I paid the least possible for somewhat quick inclusion
2. I was essentially guaranteed to be included

author: butta
content: what they really want is a tx cost of a few pennies :p

author: sky.cactus
content: Sure, but solving that problem is much harder and longer term.

author: sky.cactus
content: And completely unrelated to EIP-1559.

author: butta
content: if ethereum scaled we would not be talking about this

author: sky.cactus
content:
"Hey, we made a better car that gets better gas mileage!"
"But what people want is space travel."
"There are people working on space travel.  In the meantime, we now have better cars."

author: sky.cactus
content: EIP-1559 is "better cars" while we work on figuring out "interplanetary space flight" (scaling).

author: sky.cactus
content: Totally different problems, with totally different solutions, even though both are "travel" related.

author: sky.cactus
content: EIP-1559 and scaling both are "gas related", but they really don't tackle the same set of problems at all.

author: sky.cactus
content: And EIP-1559 is *far* simpler than scaling.  Many orders of magnitude simpler in fact.

author: barnabemonnot
content: still not, you could set max fee = 2 gwei + 7 wei and priority fee = 2 gwei, if 2 gwei was the cutoff for miners. you could also set maxfee = 7 wei and never be included because you would never give enough tip to the miners

author: barnabemonnot
content: and you can also do that: set priority fee = max fee = whatever value you wanted to low ball to, you will get certainty to be included at gas price = priority fee = max fee (and you probably won't overpay from the large priority fee because you'd be included when basefee decreases, i.e., included as soon as effective priority fee > miner fee cutoff)

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't follow gas price trends, I don't watch charts, I don't know the seasonality of gas prices, I don't follow gas guzzlers.

author: sky.cactus
content: Not if my time is worth more than I save.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is non-zero effort (time, work, money) to be a trader.  If I'm doing one transaction a week, it isn't worth my time to highly optimize that one trade.

author: sky.cactus
content: I am far better off using a simple heuristic that will let me not think about the problem and get me a reasonably good deal at the moment of submission.

author: sky.cactus

author: sky.cactus
content: I feel like you may be thinking the demographic of Ethereum users is different from reality.

author: sky.cactus
content: I see a *ton* of users trying to use Ethereum who barely understand how to use a computer.

author: sky.cactus
content: Many who just want to buy some game token, or a piece of art they like, or participate in some sale a friend of a friend told them about.

author: sky.cactus
content: These are very much not expert traders.  They don't understand anything about Ethereum.

author: sky.cactus
content: They just want to buy or sell something like on Amazon.

author: sky.cactus
content: The only thing you need to do is literally set the max fee to the max you are willing to pay.  That is it, your wallet should do the rest automatically.

author: sky.cactus

author: sky.cactus
content: Bidding 1000 isn't always bad.

author: sky.cactus
content: If you have a high time preference 1000 may be reasonable.  Also, we have zero guarantees that 1000 will not be sustained indefinitely.

author: sky.cactus
content: We used to think that 20 was the highest we would see for any extended period.

author: sky.cactus
content: And that was back when the price of ETH was below 100, so that meant sub pennie transactions!

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: quarterly / yearly trends can be understood by wallets

author: ghosts_in_the_code

author: sky.cactus
content: The trends aren't stably repeating over those time scales.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: not repeating

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: but a wallet can see this is what's going on past 3 months lets define good and bad in our wallet for next 3 months like this

author: sky.cactus
content: That is the wallet trying to predict the future.  It is a **really** hard problem.

author: sky.cactus
content: There is an entire industry (finance) built around exclusively this and they still haven't figured it out perfectly and they very often fail spectacularly.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: decent prediction better than no prediction

author: sky.cactus
content: You can say stuff like, "property prices always go up", which is true until it isn't.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm not saying wallets can't or even shouldn't try to predict the future.  I'm saying that when designing a system, we need to strive to design something that doesn't depend on someone solving a problem that historically has never been solved.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: property price is fundamentally different from blockspace market, if everyone predicts property goes up, it'll get bought up today and hence priced in and hence no edge. blockspace can be simultaneously predictable in the future and yet there not be a way to defeat that prediction today

author: sky.cactus
content: EIP-1559 is a system that functions butter than the legacy system if we assume that predicting the future is not possible.  It also gracefully degrades to the legacy system for end users if that assumption is false.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: making a guess that last 3 months average = next 3 months average is trivial and has some validity

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: (more specifically if bidding 1000 was bad last 3 months its prolly bad next 3 months)

author: sky.cactus
content: We have seen over 1000 last for hours I believe.  Many users have a time preference greater than hours.

author: sky.cactus
content: And we have seen over 500 I think for days, and over 100 for weeks maybe?

author: sky.cactus
content: It is very non trivial to factor in time preference beyond "I want in now".

author: sky.cactus
content: As soon as your time preference becomes an arbitrarily shaped curve, communicating that between the user and the UI becomes an incredibly hard problem.

author: sky.cactus
content: Thus, for the simplest UX (a design goal for many wallets), we pick an assumed time preference of "now or never" and build a UX around that.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: thats very rare circumstance. if someone is left waiting with gas at 1000 for an hour, they can replace by fee, its not a circumstance to optimise for

author: sky.cactus
content: The optimization isn't for 1000 specifically, it is for designing a UI that doesn't need to account for complex differences in time preference.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: and that default UI shouldnt bid 1000, either pre or post 1559, all im saying

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: (and if someone is bidding 1000 personally its likely because they have enough capital to not care about such things)

author: sky.cactus
content: 1000 is an arbitrary cherry picked number, and we shouldn't be hard coding things like that.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: (or some rare situation where bidding 1000 actuallt makes sense)

author: sky.cactus
content: Is 900 "too much"?  What about 500?  100?  50?

author: sky.cactus
content: We aren't dealing with a discontinuous system, it is continuous and for each user time preference differs so there is not one solution that works for everyone.

author: sky.cactus
content: There are *fewer* users with a time preference of 1000 than there are with a time preference of 900, but both exist and everything in between.

author: sky.cactus
content: There is not some obvious line in the sand where we can say "this specific time preference pricing curve captures enough users".

author: sky.cactus
content: So instead we choose the far simpler solution of just assuming everyone has a now-or-never time preference which lets us remove the "price" from the equation entirely.

author: sky.cactus
content: Which turns the curve just into a boolean.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: soft-code then ... imo wallets can be smart to look at gasprice at 500 and say, "right now gasprices are very high, recommended coming back later if you want cheaper fee" or an "are you sure" dialogue if someone overrides (in any situation) and says 1000

author: sky.cactus
content: In fact, Geth **did** do this (hard coded a 500 nanoeth/gas limit) and it caused some problems!

author: sky.cactus
content: This would not be an unreasonable differentiating factor for wallets.

author: sky.cactus
content: Something simple like a warning that "gas prices are higher than normal right, now consider doing your thing later".

author: sky.cactus
content: I wouldn't be opposed to something like that, and in fact I think in general I would support it.

author: sky.cactus
content: It isn't a hard stop, but it does let the novice user know that they might be able to save a bit of money by just doing their thing at a different time.  It also helps inform them that fees are variable in a way that isn't too intrusive.

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: Yup. Imo most improvements worth doing at wallet level anyway not protocol. Can even cater different experiences to users of different DeFi apps or wealth brackets if wallets want to go that route

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: Yup but that's an active choice, to focus on only those users who have very immediate time preference (next few blocks no matter what)

author: ghosts_in_the_code
content: Idk if it represents majority of users

author: sky.cactus
content: Agreed.  I think 1559 opens some doors on improved UX for *some* users, but by design you can continue utilizing the same strategies you used before.
